questionText.text: What does the analogy “AI is the new electricity” refer to?

options.option: Through the “smart grid”, AI is delivering a new wave of electricity.
Similar to electricity starting about 100 years ago, AI is transforming multiple industries.
AI runs on computers and is thus powered by electricity, but it is letting computers do things not possible before.
AI is powering personal devices in our homes and o ces, similar to electricity.

questions.correct_feedback: Correct. Yes. AI is transforming many elds from the car industry to agriculture to supply-chain...

questionText.text: Which of these are reasons for Deep Learning recently taking o ? (Check the two options that apply.)

options.option: We have access to a lot more computational power
Deep learning has resulted in signi cant improvements in important applications such as online advertising, speech recognition, and image recognition.
Neural Networks are a brand new eld.
We have access to a lot more data.

questions.correct_feedback: ['option-1: Yes! The development of hardware, perhaps especially GPU computing, has significantly improved deep learning algorithms' performance.','option-2: Yes! The digitalization of our society has played a huge role in this.']

questionText.text: Recall this diagram of iterating over di erent ML ideas. Which of the statement below true? (Check all that apply.)

options.option: Being able to try out ideas quickly allows deep learning engineers to iterate more quickly.
Faster computation can help speed up how long a team takes to iterate to a good idea.
It is faster to train on a big dataset than a small dataset.

options.optText: Recent progress in deep learning algorithms has allowed us to train good models faster (even without changing the CPU/GPU hardware).

questions.correct_feedback: ['option-1: Yes, as discussed in Lecture 4.','option-2: Yes, as discussed in Lecture 4.']

questionText.text: When an experienced deep learning engineer works on a new problem, they can usually use insight from previous problems to train a good model on the rst try, without needing to iterate multiple times through di erent models. True/False?

options.option: True
False

questions.correct_feedback: Correct Yes. Finding the characteristics of a model is key to have good performance. Although experience can help, it requires multiple iterations to build a good model.

questionText.text: Which one of these plots represents a ReLU activation function?

options.option: Figure-1
Figure 2:
Figure 3:
Figure 4:

questions.correct_feedback: Correct! This is the ReLU activation function, the most used in neural networks.

questionText.text: Images cat recognition is an example of “structured” data, because it is Quiz, 10 questions represented as a structured array in a computer. True/False?

options.option: True
False

questions.correct_feedback: Yes. Images for cat recognition is an example of “unstructured” data.

questionText.text: A demographic dataset with statistics on di erent cities' population, GDP per capita, economic growth is an example of "structured" data by opposition to image, audio or text datasets.

options.option: True
False

questions.correct_feedback: Correct. A demographic dataset with statistics on di erent cities' population, GDP per capita, economic growth is an example of "structured" data by opposition to image, audio or text datasets.

questionText.text: Why is an RNN (Recurrent Neural Network) used for machine translation, say translating English to French? (Check all that apply.)

options.option: It can be trained as a supervised learning problem.
It is strictly more powerful than a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN).
It is applicable when the input/output is a sequence (e.g., a sequence of words).
RNNs represent the recurrent process of Idea->Code->Experiment->Idea->....

questions.correct_feedback: Correct. Yes. An RNN can map from a sequence of english words to a sequence of french words.

questionText.text: In this diagram which we hand-drew in lecture, what do the horizontal axis (x-axis)and to  vertical axis (y-axis) represent?

options.option:
x-axis is the amount of data
y-axis is the size of the model you train.

x-axis is the performance of the algorithm
y-axis (vertical axis) is the amount of data.

x-axis is the input to the algorithm
y-axis is outputs.

x-axis is the amount of data
y-axis (vertical axis) is the performance of the algorithm.
